Programming-for-AI-2024.title: Programming For AI
Programming-for-AI-2024.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Programming-for-AI-2024.courseDescription: This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the fundamentals of programming in Python, tailored for students embarking on their journey into AI and ML. Throughout the course, students will gain hands-on experience by implementing essential AI/ML tasks from scratch. The curriculum provides an in-depth exploration of fundamental Python data types, functions, loops, conditional statements, tuples, lists, and dictionaries. Additionally, students will be exposed to the powerful libraries in Python such as Pandas, NumPy, SciPy, Matplotlib, and Seaborn, equipping them with the tools necessary for sophisticated data analysis and visualization. As part of the exercise sets, students will engage in practical data analysis using real-world datasets from neuroscience, and implement core AI/ML tasks, including the training of artificial neural networks (ANNs), backpropagation, $k$-means clustering, and $k$-nearest neighbor classification, all from scratch. The course is designed to facilitate students who intend to pursue projects in deep learning and/or reinforcement learning in their subsequent semesters.

Probability-2024.title: Probability And Stochastic Processes
Probability-2024.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Probability-2024.courseDescription:
This is a graduate-level course on probability, with emphasis on development of concepts from a measure-theoretic perspective. The course will delve into the notions of $\sigma$-algebras, random variables as measurable functions, expectations as abstract integrals, and some aspects of convergence of sequences of random variables.

This course is cross-listed with EE5817: Random Variables and Stochastic Processes.

list.title: Course logistics.

Functions, cardinality, countability, examples of countable sets, proof of countability of $\mathbb{Q}$, uncountable sets, examples of uncountable sets, proof of uncountability of $\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}$ via Cantor's diagonalisation argument.

Motivation for an axiomatic theory of probability -- Bertrand's paradox, definition of sample space, definition of algebra, need for $\sigma$-algebra, definition of $\sigma$-algebra, events, measurable sets, measurable space, measure, measure space, finite measure, infinite measure, probability measure, probability space.

Properties of probability measures, the union bound, the $\liminf$ (all but finitely many) event, the $\limsup$ (infinitely many or infinitely often) event, continuity of probability measure, probability measures on discrete (countable) sample spaces, probability measures on uncountable probability measures, Borel $\sigma$-algebra, $\mathscr{B}([0,1])$, Caratheodory's extension theorem, Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}([0,1])$, $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$ and Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$, Cantor set -- construction, properties, and Lebesgue measure.

Conditional probability measure, law of total probability, Bayes' Theorem, independence of a collection of events, independence of a collection of $\sigma$-algebras, Borel-Cantelli lemma, random variables and measurability, probability law of a random variable, cumulative distribution function (CDF) and its properties.

Discrete random variables, probability mass function (PMF), CDF from PMF, examples of discrete random variables, continuous random variables, probability density function (PDF), examples of continuous random variables, multiple random variables, definition of a pair of random variables as a measurable function, joint probability law of two random variables, joint CDF of two random variables.

<span>Properties of joint CDF of two random variables, marginal CDFs from joint CDF, probability law and joint CDF of multiple random variables, jointly discrete random variables, joint PMF, marginal PMFs from joint PMF, conditional PMF, jointly continuous random variables, joint PDF, example where two random variables are individually continuous but not jointly continuous.

<span>Joint PDF of jointly continuous random variables, properties of joint PDF, conditional PDF, functions of random variables, definition of Borel-measurable functions, showing that maximum and minimum of random variables are random variables and deriving their corresponding CDFs, showing that the sum of two random variables is a random variable, convolution formula for the PMF/PDF of the sum of two random variables when the participating random variables are jointly discrete/continuous, showing that the sum of random number of random variables is a random variable.

<span>Deriving the CDF of random sum of random variables, Jacobian formula for single and multivariable transformations, primer on Riemann integration, expectation of a simple random variable, expectation of a non-negative random variable, expectation of an arbitrary random variable, preliminary properties of expectation.

<span>Expectations of simple random variables, primer on real analysis: supremum and infimum of a set of real numbers, supremum and infimum of a sequence of real numbers, limit supremum and limit infimum of a sequence of real numbers, limit of a sequence of real numbers, demonstrating that supremum, infimum, limit supremum, and limit infimum of a sequence of random variables is a extended real-valued random variable.

<span>Pointwise convergence of a sequence of random variables, construction of a monotone sequence of simple random variables that converge pointwise to a non-negative random variable, Monotone Convergence Theorem or MCT (a simpler version based on pointwise convergence) and expectations of non-negative random variables via MCT, expectations of discrete random variables via PMF, expectations on different spaces.

<span>Expectations on different spaces (continued), absolute continuity of measures, Radon--Nikodym theorem, expectations of continuous random variables, variance, covariance, uncorrelated random variables, independence and uncorrelatedness.

<span>Uncorrelatedness and independence (continued), correlation coefficient, Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, $\mathcal{L}^{p}$ vector spaces (for $1 \leq p < +\infty$), $\mathcal{L}^2$ vector space and inner products, interpretation of correlation coefficient as cosine of the angle for zero-mean random variables, conditional expectations -- introduction, computation of conditional expectation for jointly discrete and jointly continuous random variables.

<span>Conditional expectations (continued), law of iterated expectations, problems on conditional expectations, conditioning on an event, some miscellaneous problems on conditional expectations, geometric interpretation of conditional expectation as minimum mean-squared error (MMSE) estimator.
<span>Probability generating functions, moment generating functions, characteristic functions.
<span>Joint moment generating functions, joint characteristic functions, inequalities: Markov's inequality, Chebyshev's inequality, Chernoff bound, Jensen's inequality.

<span>Jointly Gaussian random variables (or multivariate Gaussian random variables or Gaussian random vectors), equivalent defintions for jointly Gaussian random variables and their proofs, convergence of sequences of random variables--pointwise convergence, convergence in distribution.

<span>Convergence of sequences of random variables (contd.), example problems on convergence, limit theorems--weak law of large numbers, strong law of large numbers, central limit theorem, importance sampling.

Stochastic-Processes-2025.title: Stochastic Processes: Theory and Applications
Stochastic-Processes-2025.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Stochastic-Processes-2025.courseDescription:
This is a graduate-level course on stochastic processes. Beginning with a rigorous treatment of the various notions of convergence of sequences of random variables, the course will touch upon the topics of stationary and wide-sense stationary processes, Bernoulli and Poisson processes, and stopping times. The heart of the course comprises a thorough and detailed exposition of the theory of discrete-time Markov chains on finite state spaces, introducing the students to the notions of irreducibility, recurrence, period, invariant distributions, and the ergodic theorem. Alongside providing theoretical foundations, the course will also provide a deep dive into simulation techniques such as importance sampling and Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) techniques.

This course is cross-listed with EE5910: Advanced Stochastic Processes.

list.title: <span>Course logistics.
<span>Primer on real analysis: supremum and infimum of a subset of real numbers, sequence of real numbers, limit supremum, limit infimum, and limit of a sequence of real numbers.
<span>Primer on probability: sample space, $\sigma$-algebra, probability measure, Borel $\sigma$-algebra of subsets of $\mathbb{R}$, random variable as a measurable function on the sample space.

<span>Random variables, some basic facts about the Borel $\sigma$-algebra $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$, probability law of a random variable, cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a random variable, introduction to random vectors and sequences of random variables.

<span>Bivariate random vectors, $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R}^2)$ and its generating class, joint probability law and joint CDF of two random variables, multi-dimensional random vectors, $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R}^n)$ and its generating class for $n>2$, joint probability law and joint CDF of multiple random variables, random sequences, sample path, finite-dimensional distributions (FDDs), $\liminf$ of a random sequence.

<span>Mathematical definitions of $\limsup$, $\liminf$, and pointwise limit of sequences of random variables, proof that $\liminf$ of a sequence of random variables is a random variable, proof that pointwise limit of a sequence of random variables (if existing) is a random variable, definition of pointwise convergence, the event $A_{\rm lim}$ and proof of its measurability, definition of almost-sure convergence as $\mathbb{P}(A_{\rm lim})=1.$

Almost-sure convergence (contd.), almost-sure uniqueness of the almost-sure limit, $\liminf$ and $\limsup$ of sequence of events (the all but finitely many and infinitely often events), Borel--Cantelli lemma, almost-sure convergence via Borel--Cantelli lemma, examples.

<span>Almost-sure convergence via Borel--Cantelli lemma (contd.), a generic template for proving almost-sure convergence using Borel--Cantelli lemma, definitions of other notions of convergence: convergence in probability, mean-squared convergence, convergence in distribution, implications, examples.
<span>Convergence notions (contd.), convergence in distribution, implications between the various notions of convergence, proofs of implications.
<span>Problems on convergence of sequences of random variables.

<span>Reverse implications: (a) convergence in distribution to a constant random variable implies convergence in probability to the same constant random variable (with proof), and (b) convergence in probability + domination implies convergence in mean-squared sense (statement only; no proof), weak law of large numbers (statement; proof using finite variance assumption; general proof using characteristic functions), strong law of large numbers (statement; proof under finite fourth moment assumption), central limit theorem (statement only).
<span>Central limit theorem (CLT): statement and proof, demonstration of CLT, interpretation of CLT, what CLT is not, local CLT.

<span>Random processes: introduction and definition, finite dimensional distributions (FDDs), consistency of FDDs, examples of different random processes, mean, autocorrelation and autocovariance of a random process, stationary and wide-sense stationary processes, IID processes, random walk on natural numbers (intro).
<span>Random walk on natural numbers (contd.), Gaussian process, stationary and independent increments in random walk, binary pseudo-random number generators (intro).

<span>Binary pseudo-random number generators (contd.), maximal sequences ($m$-sequences), autocorrelation of a binary $m$-sequence, non-binary PRNGs, the power residue method, $\sigma$-algebra generated by a random variable, filtrations, stopping time (intro.).

<span>Discrete stopping times, alternative definition of stopping time property for discrete stopping times, Wald's lemma for stopping times with respect to IID processes, example application of Wald's lemma.

<span>Proof of Wald's lemma, recap of monotone convergence theorem (MCT), demonstration of application of MCT in the proof of Wald's lemma, strong independence property, properties of stopping times: minimum of two stopping times is a stopping time, sum of two stopping times taking values in a separable index set is a stopping time (under the assumption that stopping times only take non-negative values).

<span>Markov chains: general definition of Markov property, discrete time Markov chains (DTMCs), state space, examples of DTMCs (snakes and ladders, random walk), Markov property for deterministic sampling times, transition probability matrix (TPM), interpretation of each row of TPM as a probability distribution on the state space (for DTMCs with a discrete state space), time homogeneous Markov chains, Chapman--Kolmogorov equation for time homogeneous DTMCs.
<span>Chapman--Kolmogorov equations (contd.), strong Markov property and its proof for time-homogeneous DTMCs, hitting times to a state.

<span>Unconditional independence of past and future conditioned on state value at hitting time, IID block structure, recurrence times, IID property of recurrence times, recurrent and transient states, mean recurrence time, positive recurrent and null recurrent states, number of visits to a state and its relation to transience and recurrence.

<span>Mean number of visits to a state and its connection to transience and recurrence, example problem, reachability, communication between states, communication is an equivalence relation, communicating classes.

<span>Proof that communication is an equivalence relation, open and closed communicating classes, class properties, irreducibility, period, proof that period is a class property, recurrence and transience are class properties (statement only), positive recurrence and null recurrence are class properties (statement only).
<span>Invariant distribution (definition), properties of invariant distribution, examples.
<span>Some important results on DTMCs and their proofs, examples.
<span>Recap of results on DTMC, ergodicity, convergence in total variation distance to stationary distribution under ergodicity.

Sampling from a distribution, inverse transform technique, generating samples from a custom PMF/PDF using inverse transform technique, decoding the functioning of numpy.random.normal via inverse transform technique and Box--Muller transformation from polar to cartesian coordinates, rejection sampling (accept-reject) technique, decoding the functioning of numpy.random.gamma via rejection sampling technique.
<span>Ergodic theorem for ergodic Markov chains on finite state space, proof of ergodic theorem, Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) techniques: motivation, Metropolis--Hastings algorithm.
<span>Some remarks on the design of acceptance matrix in the Metropolis--Hastings algorithm.

<span>Application of the Metropolis--Hastings algorithm to Bayesian logistic regression based on the Challenger O Ring dataset, simulation tidbits: test for irreducibility, Kolmogorov's extension theorem and sample paths of a random process in simulations.

Probability-2025.title: Probability And Stochastic Processes
Probability-2025.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Probability-2025.courseDescription:
This is a graduate-level course on probability, with emphasis on development of concepts from a measure-theoretic perspective. The course will delve into the notions of $\sigma$-algebras, random variables as measurable functions, expectations as abstract integrals, and some aspects of convergence of sequences of random variables.

This course is cross-listed with EE5817: Random Variables and Stochastic Processes.

courseContents.title: Course Contents
courseContents.description: Functions, cardinality, countability, sample space, events, algebra, $\sigma$-algebra, probability measure, properties of probability measures, continuity of probability, conditional probability and Bayes' Theorem, independence of events, random variables and measurability, functions of random variables, expectations as Lebesgue integrals, independence of random variables, computer simulation of random variables, moment generating function, characteristic function, Borel-Cantelli lemma, strong law of large numbers, weak law of large numbers, central limit theorem, sequences of random variables and their convergence, Gaussian random vectors.

courseContents.title: Notes
courseContents.description: This section will be updated with the slides used in class. As the classes progress, the notes from previous lectures will be made available accordingly. The slides provided here do not include the handwritten annotations used for in-class explanations. If you wish to access the annotated slides, please contact me directly.

list.title: Course logistics.

Functions, domain, co-domain, range, image, pre-image, injection, surjection, bijection, cardinality, finite sets, countably infinite sets, countable sets, examples of countably infinite sets ($\mathbb{N}, \mathbb{Q}, \mathbb{Z}$, the set of prime numbers, the set of odd natural numbers, the set of even natural numbers), proof that $\mathbb{Q}$ is countably infinite.

Proof that $\mathbb{Q}$ is countably infinite (contd.), countable union of countable sets is countable (with proof), uncountable sets, examples of uncountable sets ($\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}, [0,1], \mathbb{R}, \mathbb{R} \setminus \mathbb{Q}$, cantor set, $2^{\mathbb{N}}$), proof that $\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}$ is uncountable, proof that $[0,1]$ is uncountable.

Cantor set and its uncountability (proof idea only), proof that $|2^A|>|A|$ for any set $A$, different levels of infinity (such as $\aleph_0=|\mathbb{N}|, \aleph_1=|2^{\mathbb{N}}|=|\mathbb{R}|, \aleph_2=|2^{\mathbb{R}}|$ and so on), a formal study of probability: Bertrand's paradox, sample space.

Probability basics: sample space, algebra (definition), examples of algebra, insufficiency of algebra (explained by considering the experiment of tossing a coin until the first head is observed), countable unions and $\sigma$-algebra (definition), examples of $\sigma$-algebra for finite and countably infinite sets.

Cylinder sets associated with finite-length binary strings, construction of $\sigma$-algebra for $\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}$ via cylinder sets, Borel $\sigma$-algebra $\mathscr{B}(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}})$, construction of $\mathscr{B}(0,1)$ by considering the collection of all open sub-intervals.
Example problems on $\sigma$-algebras, construction of $\mathscr{B}[0,1]$, construction of $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$, different generating classes for $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$.

Measure, finite measure, infinite measure, probability measure, Kolmogorov's axioms of probability, properties of probability measure: finite additivity, complement property, monotonicity, inclusion-exclusion principle, limit infimum (liminf) of a sequence of events, limit supremum (limsup) of a sequence of events, limit of a sequence of events, examples of liminf and limsup sets, continuity of probability measure (statement).

Proof of continuity property of probability measure: (a) proof for non-decreasing sequence of sets, (b) proof for non-increasing sequence of sets, (c) proof for general case using (a) and (b), examples of probability assignment for countable sample spaces.

Probability assignment for uncountable sample spaces: construction of Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}(0,1)$, construction of Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$, properties of Lebesgue measure.

Independence of two events, self-independent events, universal independence of probability $0/1$ events, independence of a finite collection of events, independence of an arbitrary collection of events, Borel-Cantelli Lemma and its proof, conditional probability measure, law of total probability, Bayes' theorem, chain rule for conditional probability.

Definition of measurable function, definition of random variable as a measurable function from sample space $\Omega$ to $\mathbb{R}$, some elementary properties of a random variable, recap of generating classes for $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$, equivalent definitions of a random variable in terms of generating classes (with proof for one of the generating classes), a simplified definition of random variable, examples of random variables, indicator function.

Probability law $\mathbb{P}_X$ of a random variable $X$, proof of the fact that $\mathbb{P}_X$ is a probability measure on $(\mathbb{R}, \mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R}))$, cumulative distribution function (CDF), properties of CDF and their proofs.

Tidbits about CDFs: can have jumps, need not be left-continuous, CDF at a point $x \in \mathbb{R}$ is zero if and only if $\mathbb{P}_X(\{x\})=0$, probability mass function (PMF), discrete random variables: definition and examples.

Continuous random variables: definition, absolute continuity of $\mathbb{P}_X$ with respect to Lebesgue measure on $(\mathbb{R}, \mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R}))$, Radon--Nikodym theorem, probability density function (PDF), properties of CDF of continuous random variable, example PDFs.
